Dialogue.Student: Hi, I’m Sarah Patel. It’s nice to meet you!
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Sarah! It’s great to meet you too. How are you feeling today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed, honestly. I just started my psychology class, and I’m really excited, but I’m struggling to speak up.
Dialogue.Counselor: I understand. It can be intimidating to find your voice in a new environment. What’s been challenging for you?
Dialogue.Student: There’s this classmate, Jenny, who seems to dominate the conversations. I find it hard to share my ideas.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds tough. It’s normal to feel overshadowed when someone is very vocal. Have you found any strategies that help you participate?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I just feel like I’m not being heard.
Dialogue.Counselor: Feeling unheard can be really frustrating. Would it help to brainstorm some ways to express your thoughts more confidently?
Dialogue.Student: That could be helpful. I’d like to feel more comfortable sharing in group discussions.
Dialogue.Counselor: Absolutely, let’s work on that together!  Maybe starting with small group discussions can help ease you in.
Dialogue.Student: That sounds like a good idea. I’ll try that.
Dialogue.Counselor: Awesome! Remember, your ideas are valuable. You have a unique perspective to bring to the group.
Dialogue.Student: Thank you! I appreciate your support.
Dialogue.Counselor: You're welcome, Sarah. Keep in mind that everyone has their own pace, and it’s okay to take your time. Let’s check in again soon!
Dialogue.Student: I would like that. See you!
Hi, it’s Sarah again.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Sarah! Good to see you back. How have things been since we last spoke?
Dialogue.Student: To be honest, I’ve been really anxious. I keep avoiding group discussions.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds difficult. What do you think is causing you to avoid those situations?
Dialogue.Student: I just feel that I’m not good enough compared to others, especially Jenny.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s okay to feel anxious about that. You’re not alone in dealing with those feelings. Have you talked to anyone about it?
Dialogue.Student: I spoke to my brother Vikram. He’s supportive, but I still feel conflicted about it.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s good that you have supportive family. Did he offer any suggestions?
Dialogue.Student: He suggested I should express my thoughts and be more confident.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds like solid advice. It can be hard to put it into practice, though. What makes you feel anxious when you think about sharing your ideas?
Dialogue.Student: I worry about being ignored or dismissed.
Dialogue.Counselor: Those feelings are valid. Maybe setting small goals, like sharing one thought in each discussion, could help you gradually build your confidence.
Dialogue.Student: That could work! I’ll try to keep that in mind.
Dialogue.Counselor: Great! Remember, it's your learning process, and everyone progresses at their own pace. You have the capability to do this.
Dialogue.Student: Thanks for reminding me. It helps a lot.
Dialogue.Counselor: Anytime, Sarah! Let’s check in next time to see how you’re doing.

Dialogue.Student: Hi there! I’m back again.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Sarah! Welcome back. How have things been working out for you?
Dialogue.Student: I’m still feeling anxious, especially with group projects. We just got assigned to work together again.
Dialogue.Counselor: I see. Being paired with Jenny might be really triggering for those feelings. How have you been handling that situation?
Dialogue.Student: I tried to contribute, but I feel like my ideas don’t really get acknowledged. I become hesitant.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s understandable. It can be disheartening to feel overlooked. Have you noticed anything that helps you speak up more?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I just end up feeling frustrated by the end of our meetings.
Dialogue.Counselor: Frustration is a completely natural reaction. Perhaps taking a moment before each meeting to jot down your points can help you feel more prepared.
Dialogue.Student: That might work! I haven’t tried that yet.
Dialogue.Counselor: Preparation can grant you more confidence. Remember, your insights are important, and it’s okay to take your own space to express them.
Dialogue.Student: I’ll give it a shot. I want to feel empowered.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a great mindset! Believe in yourself, Sarah. Change takes time, but you’re on the right track.
Dialogue.Student: Thank you! I appreciate your encouragement.
Dialogue.Counselor: You’re welcome! I’m here to support you. Let’s talk again after your presentation and see how it went.

Dialogue.Student: Hi! I’m back with some updates.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Sarah! I’m glad to see you again. How did your project presentation go?
Dialogue.Student: I decided to assert myself, but I was still so nervous. I felt like I was shaking!
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s completely understandable. How did you feel afterwards?
Dialogue.Student: I shared my ideas, but I was worried they wouldn’t be well received.
Dialogue.Counselor: It takes real bravery to put yourself out there. What was the feedback like?
Dialogue.Student: It was good! Some of my teammates even agreed with my points.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s fantastic to hear! It sounds like your preparation paid off.
Dialogue.Student: It did! I realized that my voice matters, even if I have to push myself a bit.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a wonderful realization, Sarah. It’s great to see you embracing your voice.
Dialogue.Student: Thank you! I feel more hopeful about future discussions now.
Dialogue.Counselor: I’m so proud of you! Keep nurturing that confidence and remember it’s all part of the learning journey.
Dialogue.Student: I definitely will! Thank you for all your support.
Dialogue.Counselor: You’re very welcome! I look forward to hearing about your next steps. Take care!
